review.title: Automatic White-Box Testing of First-Order Logic Ontologies
review.abstract: A long-standing dream of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has pursued to encode commonsense knowledge into computer programs enabling machines to reason about our world and problems. This work offers a new practical insight towards the automatic testing of first-order logic (FOL) ontologies. We introduce a novel fully automatic white-box testing framework for first-order logic (FOL) ontologies. The application of the proposed testing method is fully automatic since a) the automated generation of tests is only guided by the syntax of axioms and b) the evaluation of tests is performed by automated theorem provers. Our proposal enables the detection of defective axioms and, additionally, it also serves to demonstrate the suitability for reasoning purposes of those formulas included into FOL ontologies. We validate our proposal by its practical application to different FOL ontologies. In particular, DOLCE ---consisting of around 200 axioms---, FPK (formal proof of the Kepler conjecture) ---which has been derived from the Flyspeck project for its use in the CADE ATP System Competition CASC-J8---, and Adimen-SUMO ---which is an ontology with more than 7,000 axioms derived from SUMO---. As result, we have detected several non-trivial defects that were hidden in those ontologies. Further, we have obtained an improved version of Adimen-SUMO (v2.6) by correcting all the defects detected during the practical application of our white-box testing method.

sections.heading: 4. A White-Box Testing Strategy
sections.text: In this section, we propose a white-box testing strategy for FOL ontologies, defined on the basis of the syntactical form of the formulas derived from their axioms; the logic behind our proposal is to ensure that the formula obtained from each axiom can be implicitly chosen by ATPs if they function through their refutation; our purpose is twofold: firstly, to detect defects; secondly, to classify axioms as suitable for argumentation; and, we assume that the reader has a certain degree of familiarity with the syntax and basic terms of FOL. We call sentences to each FOL formula that all their variable operations are within the framework (or bound by) of a quantification formula; and, we use capitalist Greek letters for (finite) sentences that can be regarded as equivalent conjunctions of all their members; and, we use Greek letters for arbitrary formulae.

sections.heading: 7. Correctness
sections.text: In this section, we will discuss the veracity of the proposed tests. As explained in sections 4 and 5, our white box testing strategy is related to the existence of redundant subformulas in disjunctive subformulas. That is, the detection of defects consists in searching for redundant subformulas, while formulas are classified as suitable when no defect can be detected. sections.heading: 8. Experimentation
sections.text: In this section, we report on the results obtained by applying our white box testing method using ATPs. First, we describe in detail and with examples the type of defects that can be detected automatically by following our proposal, and also the different levels of suitability in which clauses can be classified. Then, we describe the process of testing KIFDOLCE, CASL-DOLCE, FPK and Adimen-SUMO in sections 8.2-8.4. Some figures on the process of testing these ontologies are summarized in Table 2. sections.heading: 8.3. Testing FPK
sections.text: Next, we review the results of the FPK tests. As described in Table 2, we have received 144,902 falsehood tests for testing 5,753 axioms, of which 37,698 are unique, and also the same amount of (unique) truth tests. In Table 5 - which follows the same structure as Table 3 - we summarize the results of the FPK tests according to the methodology for classifying the tests described in Section 3. 581 falsehood tests (NP column, 1.54% of the total) are classified as non-transferable. Analysis of the evidence shows that most of the defects detected are trivial redundancies. This is not surprising since the goal of the Flyspeck project checks every logical inference, including trivial ones. sections.text: In this section we describe the process of testing and improving Adimen-SUMO v2.4 by correcting all of the defects mentioned above. As a result, we obtained the testing of 1,622 axioms (58.24% of the 2,785 clauses). Among the proposed tests are unique (see Table 2).The results of testing Adimen-SUMO v2.4 by following the methodology in Section 3 are summarized.

sections.heading: 9. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: A long-standing dream of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been pursued to enrich computer programs with the common sense that allows machines to think about our world [22]. This work provides a new practical insight into the automatic testing of first-order logic (FOL) ontologies. Next, we review the main contributions and results contained in this paper and discuss future work. To the best of our knowledge, our proposal is the first attempt to fully test the ontologies of FOL using ATPs. In addition, we provide formal evidence of the correctness of the proposed tests and report on the practical application of our methodology to four different FOL ontologies: Adimen-SUMO, KIF-DOLCE strategies, CASL-DOLCE and FPK. Through our methodology, we have been able to identify some shortcomings that have arisen in the last two years.
